pullRequest.title: Address CVE-2020-1938
pullRequest.bodyText:
The AJP protocol is enabled by default in Tomcat versions < 7.0.100,
with the AJP connector listening in TCP port 8009 by default. This is
low impact on PXF because PXF should only be accessible from segments
collocated with the PXF Server. It is important to note that mitigation
is only required if an AJP port is accessible to untrusted users.
Tomcat 7.0.100 disables AJP protocol by default

commit.message:
Address CVE-2020-1938

The AJP protocol is enabled by default in Tomcat versions < 7.0.100,
with the AJP connector listening in TCP port 8009 by default. This is
low impact on PXF because PXF should only be accessible from segments
collocated with the PXF Server. It is important to note that mitigation
is only required if an AJP port is accessible to untrusted users.

Tomcat 7.0.100 disables AJP protocol by default

beforeCommit.message:
URL decode custom header values when the X-GP-ENCODED-HEADER-VALUES is true

Starting in Tomcat version 7.0.100, HTTP header validation was tightened
disallowing invalid header values. These changed in Tomcat were a side
effect of fixes for CVE-2020-1935. This issue manifests when a table is
created with non printable delimiters, for example:

    CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE foo ()
    LOCATION ('pxf://some/path?PROFILE=demo&SERVER=demo')
    FORMAT 'CSV' ( DELIMITER E'\x01' );

The delimiter value is passed to PXF Server in an HTTP header, however
unencoded. This is causing Tomcat to drop headers with invalid header
values, and causing PXF to behave incorrectly.

In this commit, we decode custom (X-GP-*) header values when the
X-GP-ENCODED-HEADER-VALUES is true.

The delimiter value is passed to PXF Server in an HTTP header, however
unencoded. This is causing Tomcat to drop headers with invalid header
values, and causing PXF to behave incorrectly.

In this commit, we decode custom (X-GP-*) header values when the
X-GP-ENCODED-HEADER-VALUES is true.

nodes.bodyText: Shouldn't we ignore case on the value as well?

nodes.bodyText: why throw this exception ? We can't recover from it, might as well throw RuntimeException and simplify method signatures
should we have unit tests that test that we trigger the logic on the header value, case insensitive and that decoding is correct ?
Did you make a change here?

URL decode custom header values when the X-GP-ENCODED-HEADER-VALUES is true

Starting in Tomcat version 7.0.100, HTTP header validation was tightened
disallowing invalid header values. These changed in Tomcat were a side
effect of fixes for CVE-2020-1935. This issue manifests when a table is

The delimiter value is passed to PXF Server in an HTTP header, however

values, and causing PXF to behave incorrectly.

In this commit, we decode custom (X-GP-*) header values when the
X-GP-ENCODED-HEADER-VALUES is true.
